Award.AwardTitle: Electrochemical Intercalation in Defective Oxide Nanosheets
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: New and improved approaches to storing electrical energy are critical for hand-held electronics and for integrating new renewable energy sources into our electrical power grid. The research focus is on finding new ways of improving the amount of energy stored in a battery or capacitor by intentionally introducing atomic-scale defects into ceramic nanosheets that form the electrodes. The ceramic nanosheets of interest are remarkably thin - only 5-10 atoms - and they display unusual properties for storing energy, resulting in better capacitors (called supercapacitors that bridge the gap between conventional capacitors and rechargeable batteries). Using new methods to measure the structural defects in the thin ceramic nanosheets and combining that knowledge with the measured electrical storage behavior provides a path to engineering new supercapacitors that may transform the way we use traditional and renewable energy sources. The project includes a team of two graduate students and two undergraduate students and reaches campus visitors of all ages who participate in the Kyocera Museum programs.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The overall technical objective is to provide the first quantitative assessment of the electrochemical effects of intentional cation defects on proton intercalation in model single-layer nanosheet systems for Faradaic supercapacitors. Model systems include nanosheets of MnO6 and VO6 octahedra, where large fractions of octahedral defects, up to 20%, may be introduced during synthesis. The cation defects include charged metal ion vacancies and MO6 octahedra that are displaced from the otherwise atomically-flat nanosheet. The defects form new proton adsorption and intercalation sites that may markedly increase the energy storage capacity. New X-ray scattering methods enable direct study of the defects in nanosheets, and the model single-layer nanosheet structure provides a platform to determine the unknown roles of defects in pseudocapacitive charge storage. The latter may be transformational by defining the ideal nano- and meso-scale structures to facilitate commercialization of supercapacitors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Storing electrical energy is of key importance to society. Devices that can rapidly charge and discharge - in 10 seconds or so - would be of great value in many technologies. Supercapacitors are one such type of device, which might be used to make improved electric vehicles, more robust and reliable electrical power grids, and improved consumer electronics. Supercapacitor technology is likely to find broad application if the charge storage capacity and long-term reliability can be improved.

     The research focused on understanding two-dimensional ceramic materials that are only 3 or 4 atoms in thickness that can be made as high surface area solids that look like crumpled newspaper. A central theme was understanding how intentionally introducing nonuniformities into the otherwise perfect 2-D arrangement of atoms might change the charge storage properties. We found that small displacements of approximately 20% of the atoms from their ideal locations in the plane of the two-dimensional sheets yielded dramatically better supercapacitor performance. In order to reach this technical understanding, it was necessary to invent a new approach to making measurements that can directly show the small atomic displacements which we correlated with the electrical properties. The critical aspect of making these measurements was the use of high energy X-rays produced by synchrotron X-ray sources, for example at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne national Laboratory.  By developing a new environmental cell for making X-ray scattering measurements, the research team was able to show for the first time that intentionally introducing atomic-scale defects dramatically improves the electrical properties. The properties of our new engineered solids are of technological interest, and are likely to find application for charge storage, and perhaps also for catalyst applications for making high value organic liquids from bioalcohols, for example.

     The project involved three graduate students and 10 undergraduate students, and relied on the use of federally-funded facilities at three different national laboratories and at Cornell University. The synchrotron-based experiments performed at these facilities provided new and unusual educational experiences for the graduate students and undergraduate students who were involved. Of the 10 undergraduate students who worked on the project, five produced senior thesis reports, and five worked for hourly wages either over the summer or during the semester. One of the 10 was a brand-new high school graduate, who went on to get a BS degree in environmental science. The other nine were engineering students with specialties in ceramic engineering or materials science.

     High school students were also impacted by the project, by performing laboratory experiments which showed how supercapacitor materials can be synthesized and characterized. The high school students visited campus either for summer enrichment experiences, or as prospective Alfred University undergraduates. The project also provided funds for developing two versions of a website intended to provide some examples of what ceramic engineering, materials science, and glass engineering science degree programs offer as career paths. Over the course of 48 months, the website received more than 8000 page views from more than 2200 users.
